title: Wronki
text:
Wronki () is a town in the <a href="Szamotu%C5%82y%20County">Szamotuły County</a>, western-central Poland, situated in the <a href="Greater%20Poland%20Voivodeship">Greater Poland Voivodeship</a> (since 1999), previously in <a href="Pi%C5%82a%20Voivodeship">Piła Voivodeship</a> (1975–1998). It is located close to the <a href="Warta%20River">Warta River</a> to the northwest of <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a> on the edge of Notec Forest, and has a population of approximately 11,000.
History.
The town's name comes from "wrona", the Polish word for a <a href="crow">crow</a>, which is also reflected in the town's coat of arms. According to local rumour, in 1002 Boleslaw the Bold was once caught offside on the banks of Wronki River. The oldest known mention of Wronki comes from 1279. Trade and crafts developed in the <a href="Late%20Middle%20Ages">Late Middle Ages</a>, due to the town's location both on the Warta river and on the trade route which connected major cities <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a> and <a href="Szczecin">Szczecin</a>. In 1932, the German-language journal Die Stimme published an article stating that in 933, a synagogue - the first in Poland - was constructed, and in 1933 Jews near Wronki celebrated what they believed to be the millennium of Jewish life in Poland. At various times Wronki was either a <a href="Royal%20city%20in%20Poland">royal town</a> of the Polish Crown or a <a href="private%20town">private town</a> of <a href="szlachta">Polish nobility</a>. Administratively it was located in the Poznań County in the <a href="Pozna%C5%84%20Voivodeship%20%2814th%20century%20to%201793%29">Poznań Voivodeship</a> in the <a href="Greater%20Poland%20Province%20of%20the%20Polish%20Crown">Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown</a>.
It was annexed by <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a> in 1793 in the <a href="Second%20Partition%20of%20Poland">Second Partition of Poland</a>, regained by Poles and included in the short-lived <a href="Duchy%20of%20Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a> in 1807, re-annexed by Prussia in 1815, and from 1871 to 1919 it also was part of <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. The name was Germanized to "Wronke" when it was part of Prussia and Germany. The population was subjected to <a href="Germanisation%20of%20Poles%20during%20the%20Partitions">Germanisation</a> policies, nevertheless it remained a center of <a href="Resistance%20movements%20in%20partitioned%20Poland%20%281795%E2%80%931918%29">Polish resistance</a>, and <a href="Poles">Poles</a> established various educational, industrial and sporting organizations, also one of the oldest Polish <a href="volunteer%20fire%20department">volunteer fire department</a>s was founded in the town. At the beginning of the 20th century, <a href="Jews">Jews</a> were 18% of the total population. After <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the number decreased because Wronki was restored to Poland after the country regainede independence, and the Jews of Wronki belonged to the German culture.
During the <a href="Occupation%20of%20Poland%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">German occupation of Poland</a> (<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>), the Polish population was subjected to mass arrests, imprisonment, massacres, deportations to <a href="Forced%20labour%20under%20German%20rule%20during%20World%20War%20II">forced labour</a> to Germany and <a href="Expulsion%20of%20Poles%20by%20Nazi%20Germany">expulsions</a> (see "<a href="Nazi%20crimes%20against%20the%20Polish%20nation">Nazi crimes against the Polish nation</a>"). In November and December 1939, inhabitants of Wronki were among Poles murdered in mass executions in <a href="M%C4%99dzisko">Mędzisko</a> and <a href="Szamotu%C5%82y">Szamotuły</a>, and in 1940 the Germans murdered 280 Poles, previously held in the local prison, in the <a href="Kobylniki%2C%20Szamotu%C5%82y%20County">Kobylniki</a> forest. In December 1939, the German police and <a href="Selbstschutz">Selbstschutz</a> expelled many Poles, mostly the <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a>, and owners of shops and workshops.
Economy.
The town is a major hub for <a href="white%20goods">white goods</a>, most notably the headquarters of <a href="Amica%20SA">Amica SA</a>, who hail from the town, and is also where <a href="Samsung%20Electronics">Samsung Electronics Manufacturing Poland</a> who produce <a href="washing%20machines">washing machines</a> and <a href="fridges">fridges</a> in the town.
The town also contains <a href="Wronki%20Prison">Wronki Prison</a>, the largest prison in Poland.
Sports.
The town is represented by <a href="Football%20in%20Poland">football</a> club <a href="B%C5%82%C4%99kitni%20Wronki">Błękitni Wronki</a>, the predecessor and successor of <a href="Amica%20Wronki">Amica Wronki</a>, who were three times <a href="Polish%20Cup">Polish Cup</a> and two times <a href="Polish%20SuperCup">Polish SuperCup</a> winners, and who competed in <a href="Ekstraklasa">Poland's top division</a> from 1995 to 2006, and in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in the early 2000s. Currently the town is home to the academy of <a href="Lech%20Pozna%C5%84">Lech Poznań</a> and the home for their reserve team, <a href="Lech%20Pozna%C5%84%20II">Lech Poznań II</a>.
Wronki co-hosted the <a href="2006%20UEFA%20European%20Under-19%20Championship">2006 UEFA European Under-19 Championship</a> and 2014 <a href="European%20Under-18%20Rugby%20Union%20Championship">European Under-18 Rugby Union Championship</a>.
Transport.
The <a href="Wronki%20railway%20station">Wronki railway station</a> is located on the <a href="Pozna%C5%84%E2%80%93Szczecin%20railway">Poznań–Szczecin railway</a>, and the city has railway connections with major Polish cities like <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a>, <a href="Szczecin">Szczecin</a>, <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a>, <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a> and <a href="Katowice">Katowice</a>.
